results.question: Which approach is best for Scrum Team in order to produce valuable Increments?
results.correct_answer: Each Scrum Team is accountable for developing functionality from beginning to end.
incorrect_answers: Each Scrum Team works on an independent set of components.
Each Scrum Team Member work only as an independent layer of the system.
Each Developer works on the component where they feel that they can contribute.

results.question: When is the Sprint Backlog created?
Why is it important that there is only one Product Owner per product?
correct_answer: It helps avoid barriers to effective communication and rapid decision-making.
Scrum Team always knows who determines the order of the Product.
It is clear who is accountable for the ultimate value of the product.
incorrect_answers: The Scrum Master knows who acts as their backup while on vacation.
It would confuse the stakeholders if they had to work with more than one person.

results.question: By what name is Carlos Estevez better known?
True or False: The Product Owner makes sure the correct stakeholders are invited to the Sprint Retrospective. They might have important instruction for team improvements.
What might indicate to a Product Owner that she needs to work more with the Scrum Team?
results.correct_answer: The Increment presented at the Sprint Review does not what she thought she had asked for.
incorrect_answers: The acceptance criteria do not appear to be complete.
She is not working full time with the Scrum Team.

results.question:
A Scrum Team has been working on a product for 9 Sprints. A new Product Owner who is new to Scrum joins the team and understands she is accountable for the Product Backlog. However, she is unsure about the purpose of the Product Backlog. She has read that the Product Backlog should be a list of all user features for the product. She goes to the Scrum Master asking where to put the other types of requirements that are going to be taken into account. Are all of the following types of requirements acceptable on a Product Backlog?
•	Stability requirements.
•	Performance requirements
•	Product Functionality.
•	Documentation.
•	Fixes.
results.correct_answer: Yes, they all belong on the Product Backlog. The Product Backlog is supposed to be the “single source of truth” for all the work for the product.
incorrect_answers: No, Product Backlog is a tool for the Product Owner. The Product Owner represents the users and stakeholders. Other types of requirements should be managed separately by the Developers. They are not the Product Owner’s concern.

results.question: Which Animal Crossing game was for the Nintendo Wii?
Which Kirby game first introduced Copy Abilities?

When was Gangnam Style uploaded to YouTube?
